subject_terms_3: Force 136 (Guerilla movement) Death customs  Military transportation  Lim, Bo Seng  Tan, Chong Tee war personalities  1942-1945 Japanese Occupation
physical_appearance: This black and white photograph captures the scene where the military vehicle carrying Lim Bo Seng's coffin has arrived at Macritchie Reservoir where he was to be laid to rest. Two officers carry Lim's portrait. The photograph shows discolouration along the right edges.
sgcool_label_text:
These documents and photographs belong to a larger part of a collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the late 1980s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.
